## Installation

`geofi` is not yet in CRAN, but can be installed from Github using

```{r, eval = FALSE}
remotes::install_github("ropengov/geofi")
```


## Municipalities

```{r municipality_map, fig.height = 8}
library(geofi)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(janitor)
library(tidyr)


municipalities <- get_municipalities(year = 2019, scale = 4500)
ggplot(municipalities) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = as.integer(kunta)))
```

## Zipcodes


```{r zipcode_map, fig.height = 8}
zipcodes <- get_zipcodes(year = 2019) 
ggplot(zipcodes) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = as.integer(posti_alue)))
```


You can add variables from Paavo data (Statistics Finland) in following manner.

```{r zipcode_with_statistics_finland, fig.height = 8}
library(pxweb)
# lets get all zipcodes and all variables
pxweb_query_list <- 
  list("Postinumeroalue"=c("*"),
                           "Tiedot"=c("*"))

# Download data 
px_data <- 
 pxweb_get(url = "http://pxnet2.stat.fi/PXWeb/api/v1/fi/Postinumeroalueittainen_avoin_tieto/2019/paavo_1_he_2019.px",
           query = pxweb_query_list)

# Convert to data.frame 
tk_data_zip <- as.data.frame(px_data, column.name.type = "text", variable.value.type = "text")

library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
tk_data_zip2 <- tk_data_zip %>%
  as_tibble() %>% 
  setNames(c("region","indicator","value")) %>% 
  spread(indicator, value)
tk_zipdata <- janitor::clean_names(tk_data_zip2)
tk_zipdata$zipcode <- substr(x = tk_zipdata$region, start = 1, stop = 5)
tk_zipdata$zipname <- gsub("^.{6}", "", tk_zipdata$region)


# Lets join with spatial data and plot the area of each zipcode
zipcodes_new <- left_join(zipcodes, tk_zipdata, by = c("posti_alue" = "zipcode"))
ggplot(zipcodes_new) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = pinta_ala), color = alpha("white", 1/3))
```

## Aggregating municipality level data using internal municipality_key-files

```{r municipalities_map, fig.height = 8}
# Lets join the municipality level data with internal municipality_key_2017-data
dat2 <- left_join(dat, municipality_key_2017, by = c("name" = "name_fi"))

# Lets aggregate at maakunta level using column mk_name
mk_data <- dat2 %>% 
  group_by(mk_name,mk_code) %>% 
  # And compute population at maakunta level
  summarise(vakiluku_2017 = sum(vakiluku_2017))

ggplot(mk_data) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = vakiluku_2017)) +
  geom_sf_text(aes(label = paste(mk_name, "\n",vakiluku_2017)), 
               size = 3, 
               color = "white")

```


Or if you prefer aggregating at vaalipiiri-level you can

```{r vaalipiiri_map, fig.height = 8}
mk_data <- dat2 %>% 
  group_by(va_name,va_code) %>% 
  # And compute population at maakunta level
  summarise(vakiluku_2017 = sum(vakiluku_2017))

ggplot(mk_data) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = vakiluku_2017)) +
  geom_sf_text(aes(label = paste(va_name, "\n",vakiluku_2017)), 
               size = 3, 
               color = "white")

```


Or if you want the population at the national level aggregated up from municipality level you can: 

```{r, national_map, fig.height = 8}
mk_data <- dat2 %>% 
  summarise(vakiluku_2017 = sum(vakiluku_2017))

ggplot(mk_data) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = vakiluku_2017)) +
  geom_sf_text(aes(label = vakiluku_2017), 
               size = 3, 
               color = "white")

```


## Interactive maps using `leaflet`-package



```{r}
library(leaflet)
library(geofi)
library(dplyr)

municipalities <- get_zipcodes(year = 2019)
municipalities_lonlat <- sf::st_transform(x = municipalities, crs = "+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84")

leaflet(municipalities_lonlat) %>% 
  addTiles() %>% 
  addPolygons(color = "coral", 
              weight = 1,
              smoothFactor = 0.5,
              opacity = 1.0,
              fillOpacity = 0.5,
    label = ~nimi,
    highlightOptions = highlightOptions(color = "white", weight = 2,
      bringToFront = TRUE))

```
